title: Introduccion
text:
[Introduccion] (Copernico Basico > ImportacioÃÅn de datos)
Tener los datos correctos en la base de datos es tan importante como tener bien configurada la carrera. Para que lo veas con un ejemplo, no es lo mismo que Paco sea la primera mujer en llegar a meta que el catorceavo hombre. En el primer caso tendr√≠a trofeo y en el segundo no. Puedes pensar que la soluci√≥n es sencilla: s√≥lo hay que poner el g√©nero correcto pero si has usado live timing durante la prueba, todo el publico ha estado viendo a Paco como primera mujer.

title: Introduccion
text:
[Introduccion] (Copernico Basico > ImportacioÃÅn de datos)
live timing durante la prueba, todo el publico ha estado viendo a Paco como primera mujer. Es importante que sepas qu√© datos vas a necesitar para poder publicar los resultados correctos. Por eso es fundamental que tengas el reglamento de la prueba en el que se especifica el tipo de clasificaciones. Y es importante que hables con el organizador o los jueces de la prueba para saber si, adem√°s de las clasificaciones que est√°n publicadas en el

title: Introduccion
text:
[Introduccion] (Copernico Basico > ImportacioÃÅn de datos)
jueces de la prueba para saber si, adem√°s de las clasificaciones que est√°n publicadas en el reglamento, existe alguna otra en la que se vayan a entregar premios. Una vez conoces las clasificaciones que se van a publicar, deber√°s incluir en Cop√©rnico todos los datos que vayas a necesitar para extraer estas clasificaciones. Un consejo: es mejor que te sobren datos que falten. Por ejemplo, en muchos reglamentos se especifica que existe un premio para locales, pero

title: Introduccion
text:
[Introduccion] (Copernico Basico > ImportacioÃÅn de datos)
Por ejemplo, en muchos reglamentos se especifica que existe un premio para locales, pero no se dice si es en la clasificaci√≥n general o se distingue por g√©neros. Tendr√°s que consultarlo con el organizador para anticiparte a los requisitos y necesidades que vas a tener que preparar. Estos son los puntos que vamos a tratar en esta lecci√≥n: Crear un archivo de importaci√≥n. 1. Datos b√°sicos 1. Atributos y otros datos 2. Importar datos 2. Asociaci√≥n de chips 3. A√±adir participantes manualmente 4.

title: Introduccion
text:
[Introduccion] (Copernico Basico > Resultados de una carrera)
En Cop√©rnico existen diferentes formas para visualizar/imprimir los resultados una vez los primeros participantes han cruzado la l√≠nea de meta. En esta asignatura se explica de forma resumida cada una de las distintas formas que podemos presentar las clasificaciones de una carrera: Exportar en CSV: relacionado con Presets. 1. Exportar en PDF: relacionado con Documentos. 2. A trav√©s de la API. 3. Para cronometrar una carrera no es imprescindible que sepas crear un preset o un

title: Introduccion
text:
[Introduccion] (Copernico Basico > Resultados de una carrera)
3. Para cronometrar una carrera no es imprescindible que sepas crear un preset o un documento. Otro cronometrador con m√°s experiencia puede crearte los presets y documentos necesarios y compartirlos contigo f√°cilmente. Aunque s√≠ es necesario que conozcas los conceptos y sepas crear un preset o un documento sencillo. Los presets y documentos m√°s complejos te los explicaremos en una lecci√≥n m√°s avanzada.

title: Categorias
text:
[Categorias] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
Son los distintos grupos, normalmente dependientes de la edad y excluyentes entre s√≠, en los que se reparten los participantes de un evento. Puedes crear categor√≠as para una carrera bas√°ndote en criterios de g√©nero y/o a√±o de nacimiento o edad del participante pero tambi√©n puede haber categor√≠as que se rijan por otros criterios, como por ejemplo ‚Äúcategor√≠a √©lites‚Äù. Para crear categor√≠as puedes hacer clic en ¬´+ A√±adir¬ª, y a√±adir√≠as las categor√≠as de 1.

title: Categorias
text:
[Categorias] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
Para crear categor√≠as puedes hacer clic en ¬´+ A√±adir¬ª, y a√±adir√≠as las categor√≠as de 1. una en una, pero tambi√©n puedes desplegar el men√∫ de creaci√≥n y crear las categor√≠as en bloque. Completa la informaci√≥n de la categor√≠a. 2. Nombre de la categor√≠a. G√©nero: hombres (¬´Masculino¬ª), mujeres (¬´Femenino¬ª) o ambos (¬´Mixto¬ª). Desde y Hasta: en el desplegable escoge ¬´A√±o¬ª (de nacimiento) o ¬´Edad¬ª dependiendo de c√≥mo quieras configurar la categor√≠a. Si escoges el valor ¬´Edad¬ª

title: Categorias
text:
[Categorias] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
dependiendo de c√≥mo quieras configurar la categor√≠a. Si escoges el valor ¬´Edad¬ª puedes especificar que el participante debe tener esa edad el d√≠a de la prueba marcando la casilla ¬´A fecha de carrera¬ª. Si no marcas la casilla, Cop√©rnico tendr√° en cuenta la edad cumplida a 31 de diciembre de ese a√±o. Por ej. una persona que cumpla 40 a√±os el 30 de diciembre, en enero de ese mismo a√±o ya ser√≠a ‚ÄúMaster 40‚Äù si no se marcase la casilla.

title: Categorias
text:
[Categorias] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
ser√≠a ‚ÄúMaster 40‚Äù si no se marcase la casilla. Las categor√≠as aparecer√°n ordenadas cronol√≥gicamente. Se mostrar√° primero la que cuenta con un valor ¬´Desde¬ª inferior. Las dem√°s aparecer√°n sucesivamente hasta la categor√≠a con el valor ¬´Desde¬ª mayor. Las categor√≠as se pueden revisar atendiendo a los iconos que aparecen junto a ellas: Cadena. Indica que entre las categor√≠as no hay solapamiento ni franja de edad o a√±os que quede fuera de cualquier categor√≠a.

title: Categorias
text:
[Categorias] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
que quede fuera de cualquier categor√≠a. Advertencia en √°mbar. Indica que hay una franja de edad o a√±os que queda fuera de cualquier categor√≠a. Hay un hueco entre categor√≠as. Advertencia en rojo. Indica que hay un solapamiento de edad o a√±os de dos categor√≠as. Una vez creadas las categor√≠as tienes dos opciones para asignarlas a los corredores. Indicar la fecha de nacimiento y g√©nero de cada participante en el csv/xlsx que uses

title: Categorias
text:
[Categorias] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
Indicar la fecha de nacimiento y g√©nero de cada participante en el csv/xlsx que uses para importar. Cop√©rnico asignar√° autom√°ticamente la categor√≠a siempre y cuando en las mismas hayas completado el valor ¬´Desde¬ª y ¬´Hasta¬ª correctamente. Indicar la categor√≠a a la que pertenece cada participante en el csv/xlsx que uses para importar. En este caso predominar√° frente a la categor√≠a que le corresponda por su edad.

title: Trofeos
text:
[Trofeos] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
Son aquellos "premios" que configurar√°s para que se muestren en la app, en el widget de trofeos, y en los presets de trofeos. Estos √∫ltimos los puedes insertar en los documentos. Es importante crear trofeos en Cop√©rnico porque te ayudar√°n a tener un mayor control sobre la prueba, ya que se visualizar√°n en el widget de trofeos, en el apartado de trofeos de las apps o en los documentos que tuvieras seleccionados presets de trofeos. Los presets de trofeos no son editables.

title: Trofeos
text:
[Trofeos] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
Los presets de trofeos no son editables. Para crear trofeos puedes hacer clic en ¬´+ A√±adir¬ª, y crear los trofeos de uno en uno, 1. pero tambi√©n puedes desplegar el men√∫ de creaci√≥n y crear los trofeos en bloque. Completa la informaci√≥n del trofeo: 2. Nombre. Tramo de c√°lculo (no tiene por qu√© coincidir con Salida-Meta). Por ejemplo, puedes crear un trofeo para mostrar el vencedor de un tramo de cronoescalada. N√∫mero de trofeos. Cuantos participantes se llevar√°n dicho trofeo.

title: Trofeos
text:
[Trofeos] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
N√∫mero de trofeos. Cuantos participantes se llevar√°n dicho trofeo. Tipo de trofeo (general, g√©nero, categor√≠a, atributo o tipo de equipo) Detalle del trofeo (aparece cuando se elige un tipo de trofeo distinto a ¬´General¬ª). Por ejemplo cuando es de g√©nero te dir√° si es para masculino, femenino o mixto.

title: Tramos
text:
[Tramos] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
Un tramo es una secci√≥n de la carrera con un punto inicial y un punto final sobre el que Cop√©rnico calcular√° todas las clasificaciones. Siempre debe existir un tramo que englobe la totalidad del recorrido, es decir, desde el punto inicial, de tipo salida hasta el punto final, de tipo meta. Si no necesitas clasificaciones de un tramo, es mejor no crearlo, ya que un exceso de tramos podr√≠a afectar al rendimiento de Cop√©rnico.

title: Tramos
text:
[Tramos] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
podr√≠a afectar al rendimiento de Cop√©rnico. Para crear tramos puedes hacer clic en ¬´+ A√±adir¬ª para a√±adirlos de uno en uno. 1. Tambi√©n puedes desplegar el men√∫ de creaci√≥n y crear los tramos en bloque. Completa la informaci√≥n del tramo. Puedes usar la imagen arrastrando el origen y final 2. de tramo para definir el punto en el que empieza y el punto en el que termina: Nombre: es el nombre que aparecer√° en la columna en la secci√≥n de

title: Tramos
text:
[Tramos] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
Nombre: es el nombre que aparecer√° en la columna en la secci√≥n de ¬´Participantes¬ª y en la ficha del atleta, as√≠ como en el live y otros plugins donde se muestran resultados. Splits: de inicio y de fin. Tipo de media: para que el atleta pueda ver su ritmo en Live el tramo debe tener definido un tipo de medida. Por ejemplo, en running utilizaremos ¬´Minutos cada km¬ª. Si quieres mostrar clasificaciones desde la salida hasta cada uno de los splits, debes crear

title: Tramos
text:
[Tramos] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
Si quieres mostrar clasificaciones desde la salida hasta cada uno de los splits, debes crear un tramo por punto cuyo inicio est√© en el punto de salida. Tal y como se muestra en la imagen anterior. Esta configuraci√≥n es la que se utiliza cuando queremos usar el live timing. Si lo que quieres es sacar una clasificaci√≥n para un tramo concreto, por ejemplo que vaya desde el punto 10K al 15K, el inicio del tramo lo situar√°s en el 10K y el final del tramo en el

title: Tramos
text:
[Tramos] (Copernico Basico > ConfiguracioÃÅn baÃÅsica de una carrera)
desde el punto 10K al 15K, el inicio del tramo lo situar√°s en el 10K y el final del tramo en el 15K. Esta configuraci√≥n la utilizaras para hacer una cronoescalada o obtener una clasificaci√≥n de un tramo patrocinado.

title: Live timing setup for PC
text:
[Live timing setup for PC] (Live & Virtual Races > Live presentation)
This level of Copernico Academy does not explain how to import or create a race in Copernico. If you do not understand the content of this lesson, we recommend you to go back to the first basic Copernico lesson. The data that live timing displays originate from the race setup, i.e. it extracts categories, intervals and trophies that you have previously set up in the race. Live Timing link To access the race live tracking URL, click on ‚ÄúPlugins‚Äù in the left side menu of Copernico

title: Live timing setup for PC
text:
[Live timing setup for PC] (Live & Virtual Races > Live presentation)
To access the race live tracking URL, click on ‚ÄúPlugins‚Äù in the left side menu of Copernico and select the Live plugin. Within the Live settings you will see a URL for live timing. Copy and paste it into another browser to load the live timing. No data will be displayed until the race starts. Here you have a short video that shows how to get the link.

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
As you have already seen in the previous lesson, Live Results is set up from "Live Plugin" in Cop√©rnico. Select the race you are preparing and click con "Pluggins" in the left menu, then select "Live Plugin" in the window. This lesson will explain the entire setup process from top to bottom of the setup. It shall explain what we can setup in this plugin and show where it will be displayed. a. Linking Live timing for PC

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
a. Linking Live timing for PC The first thing you find when you select this plugin is the live timing link for PC, which we explained in the previous lesson. b. General race information This information is common to all events in the race, i.e. even if you switch from one event to another you will see the same information. In the section you will know how to: Enable push notifications When activated, Cop√©rnico will send notifications to all users who have the app installed

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
When activated, Cop√©rnico will send notifications to all users who have the app installed and has marked as favourite at least one participant. They will receive a notification every time one of these participants passes through a split in the race. If a user has marked their club mates as favourites in the app, they will receive a push notification every time each of them passes through a split. "John Smith has passed km 1". This service has an extra fee (please consult with a sales manager).

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
This service has an extra fee (please consult with a sales manager). Race hashtag (Add Twitter to the app) By adding Twitter to the app, users will be able to tweet directly in the app from their own Twitter accounts using a hashtag that you previously setup. You do not need to link your app

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
to any particular Twitter account to enable this option. As you can appreciate in the following picture, once configured, the twitter symbol appears below race photos. Videos You can upload a video (or several videos), for the live broadcast or a simple promotional video of the race or of a city, as an example. Complete the necessary information for the video broadcast: Descriptive name of the video: this is the name displayed in the app.

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
Descriptive name of the video: this is the name displayed in the app. Video provider type: provider of the video (only YouTube is available). Stream URL: YouTube link. Source ID: a code you find in the Youtube link. It is displayed following the symbol ¬´/¬ª in its short version, as in an example below, the code is in bold: https://youtu.be/R70ASQytLOc There is a whole lesson about Cop√©rnico Video explaining all the live video functionalities and how to set up a video replay.

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
and how to set up a video replay. Click on the "+ Add" button to continue adding more videos click and when you are done click on the "Save" button. As you can see in the image, the video is displayed at the bottom left and will change automatically if you have uploaded more than one video. The videos are shared by all the events, as they are configured for the race: Once the video is uploaded, it will look as shown below:

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
c. Events Although everything you have set up above is related to the race and includes all events, you can activate, change or modify some of the elements of "Live Results" for each event. Let's review the options you can configure within events: Geolocation By enabling this option you allow your event participants with the app installed to share their position by GPS if they agreed to. Those app users who have selected them as

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
their position by GPS if they agreed to. Those app users who have selected them as favourites or who are looking for them, will be able to see their location sent via the athlete's GPS. Always within the route that you have previously uploaded. Geolocation is activated for each event as you may want to activate it for the participants of the "Marathon" event but not for the participants of the "5K" event.

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
the "Marathon" event but not for the participants of the "5K" event. There is an additional cost for this service. This service cannot be used as live tracking and does not work for virtual races. We explain more about geolocation in this timingsense Academy article. Live's start time Live's start time is not linked to the actual start time of the events, but is the time that will appear in the event's countdown in the application. This time does not have to correspond to

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
appear in the event's countdown in the application. This time does not have to correspond to the start time you have set in Cop√©rnico. In the application this time is displayed at the top of the screen: Time prediction By activating this option, Cop√©rnico will use the predictive algorithm. Its operation is

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
simple, although you should note the following: It does not make sense to activate it for an event with only "start" and "finish" points 1. because the accuracy is very low with only two splits. It is more accurate from three intermediate locations onwards, and the more intermediate points the better for accuracy. The slopes of the course affect it quite a lot, so in trail events it is difficult to be 2. accurate.

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
2. accurate. It is very important to complete the data properly and to be as accurate as possible, as 3. this will be used for the calculations. Data from previous editions of the same event and same course can help you a lot to 4. complete the correct data. To activate the time prediction, click on the checkbox "Will the time prediction be displayed?". When you do so, new fields that must be filled in will appear.

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
displayed?". When you do so, new fields that must be filled in will appear. Estimated starting time of the last runner: if you have no idea how long it will take, you can use this rule of thumb as a guide; in an 8-metre arc about 1000 runners per minute. Predictive: for the predictive time to work properly you must complete the time information between intervals. The interval distance is the data you must use to calculate

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
information between intervals. The interval distance is the data you must use to calculate the time and always indicate the minimum time for the interval, i.e. In the example you can see that there are 4 sections: one from the split "Start" to the spit "Km 1", one from "Km 1" to the split "Km 2", one from "Km 2" to "Km 3" and one from "Km 3" to "Km 4". We were able to set the same times in the four intervals, as the distance between them was

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
We were able to set the same times in the four intervals, as the distance between them was the same: 1 km. Thus, we set the time of the fastest athlete (2 min 50 sec) and the time of the slowest athlete (8 min). Paces of 2:50 min/km for the fastest athlete and 8 min/km for the slowest athlete were taken into account. This example was easy because we only had two intervals and they were both the same distance. Standard running paces are usually between 3 min/km and 9 min/km. These paces can

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
distance. Standard running paces are usually between 3 min/km and 9 min/km. These paces can change in trail events. Hence the importance of data from previous years. Note that here we are talking about the time it takes to complete the interval, not like in the minimum and maximum split times. Here you will always complete the time it takes the fastest to complete that interval and also the slowest. Split

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
fastest to complete that interval and also the slowest. Split In this drop-down you can enable different options of each split of the event. Keep in mind

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
that even having several events sharing the same location, you have to set them up individually. For example, you may want to broadcast video in one of the events and not in others. You can see a possible setup in the picture below: This picture shows: "Start" Split has a setup for video (which will be a live video), "5K" Split is hidden on the map, and "Finish" Split has got Live video and Replay video. Let's see what it means and what you have to do in order to setup each of them:

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
Let's see what it means and what you have to do in order to setup each of them: Video (Live Video): Fill in the required data for the video broadcast: name, the type of video provider, URL and the ID of the resource. These videos can be recorded with any camera or mobile phone that allows YouTube live broadcasting. The user will be able to see these videos by tapping on a split on the course map of the app.

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
The user will be able to see these videos by tapping on a split on the course map of the app. A screen of the selected split will open, where the video and the times of the participants will be loaded (img). Hide a split on the event map: by checking the "Hide on map" checkbox, the split will not be selectable from the application map. Times and positions will still be received, each participant will be able to see their time and position in that split and Push notifications will also be sent.

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
Push notifications will also be sent. Participants will be able to view their video replay at any time by going to their ranking and clicking on the camera icon of the split they want to watch.

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
Video replays are very useful to clarify possible disputes. It can be useful when you want to check who has crossed the finish line first or in a specific position. To find a video replay, search for the participant and tap on the video icon in the split you want to review. There is an additional cost for video replays. In the next picture you can see how it looks when its hidden on the map. We created an exclusive lesson for you to take your video broadcasts to the next level. See

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
We created an exclusive lesson for you to take your video broadcasts to the next level. See Lesson C8 - Cop√©rnico Video (enlazar) Map / Route You can upload the race route in gpx, kmz or kml format so that it can be displayed in the app. When uploading the file you must verify that the intermediate points are in the correct location: they are the ones that appear with the white icon. You can also verify them with

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
location: they are the ones that appear with the white icon. You can also verify them with the distance of each one in the left side menu. The starting line is represented with an icon similar to a play button and the finish line with a finish line arch icon. The user will be able to view this route on the home page of the app for each event. Once the route has been uploaded, the slope of the event can also be displayed.

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
the route has been uploaded, the slope of the event can also be displayed. In the example there is only one intermediate point at km 5 and, as you can see, it is correctly located: If you are going to time a race with start and finish at the same location, you will notice that when you upload the route, the difference between the two splits is not distinguishable on the map. It may happen that the real course does not have the same distance as the file you

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
the map. It may happen that the real course does not have the same distance as the file you have uploaded to Cop√©rnico. And you will see this because the start and finish points do not match. To solve this, select and drag any of the two points and place it on top of the other.

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
It is also possible that the intermediate splits do not exactly match the physical location where the timing devices will be placed. If this happens, drag them around the course, or increase/decrease the distance by changing the number or moving the course bar. You can see in these videos: How to create the route in Google Earth for a race. How to trace the course of a triathlon in Google Earth. How to trace all triathlon events on Google Earth. Athlete profile

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
How to trace all triathlon events on Google Earth. Athlete profile You can configure the data you want to be displayed for each athlete in the application. The athlete sheet can be setup at the beginning and it is mandatory to have at least one registered athlete to be able to set it up. The application users will be able to check each participant's information by clicking on the "More info" button that appears when consulting the ranking.

title: Live results setup
text:
[Live results setup] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
"More info" button that appears when consulting the ranking. At the moment it does not work when the results are consolidated, i.e. once we have published race results.

title: Create and publish a race
text:
[Create and publish a race] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
As you have learned from previous lessons, for the race to be displayed in the application it should be first created and published in Sportmaniacs. Essential data to create a race and its events: Name Date of start and finish of the race (merely informative). Place Time zone Currency Default language Essential data to publish a race. In basic information: Return policy. If it is not available, you can insert a link to the race regulations website.

title: Create and publish a race
text:
[Create and publish a race] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
Return policy. If it is not available, you can insert a link to the race regulations website. Information on the place of start: If it is not available, you can insert a link to the race website or race regulations. Bib-number pick-up: If it is not available, you can insert a link to the race website or race regulations. In Regulations Norms: copy and paste Regulations text or insert a link on race regulations webpage.

title: Create and publish a race
text:
[Create and publish a race] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
In Regulations Norms: copy and paste Regulations text or insert a link on race regulations webpage. When you fill in all this, click on "Save and publish" to publish your race in Sportmaniacs.

title: Live Timing for PC
text:
[Live Timing for PC] (Live & Virtual Races > Live presentation)
A mere fact of timing with Cop√©rnico will make you enjoy Live timing for PC. This type of live timing is very simple: it displays only five participants in each of the options, for example, in each of the categories. In different sections' rankings it displays 100 participants. This live timing the following in each event: Leaders: the top of your race, 5 first athletes of each gender and 5 first athletes for each category. Intervals: first 100 participants on each interval of your race.

title: Live Timing for PC
text:
[Live Timing for PC] (Live & Virtual Races > Live presentation)
each category. Intervals: first 100 participants on each interval of your race. Trophies: you will be able to see all those trophies you have created for each of the events. It also allows you to search for any participant and see all his results and rankings using the upper search bar and adding them as a favorite to track. Note: This Live timing is NOT editable. If you wish customization you should use the Live app.

title: Enable your race as virtual
text:
[Enable your race as virtual] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
You can read a full article about it in timingsense Academy. Here is a quick overview of the necessary steps: Participants can train for the race when you activate a race to virtual. We will talk about the trainings in detail in the next article. In order for participants to be validated, you should import registered participants. Later we will look into different import options. All dates in virtual events are setup in the Sportmaniacs application panel. Access to the panel

title: Introduction
text:
[Introduction] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
As you could see in the previous lesson, there are multiple places where you have to complete information to make it visible in the app. This is mainly due to the data consumption. Cop√©rnico is an entirely online timing software, therefore, all the calculations that are carried out to obtain participants' results are processed on online servers, which has a much higher cost than the servers in which you store race information and where you do not have to perform any type of calculation..

store race information and where you do not have to perform any type of calculation.. In this lesson we will only look at the information managed from Cop√©rnico, which is the one displayed in "Live Results" section of any application in the timingSense ecosystem. All the information shown in this lesson is managed by "Live" plugin. We are going to see the following sections in this lesson:

title: How to cast video
text:
[How to cast video] (Live & Virtual Races > Copernico Video)
To broadcast a video in the app you need the URL of the stream and the resource ID of the video: if a third party broadcasts it, it will be provided to you and if you broadcast it yourself, you have to generate the resource ID. What is the stream URL? It is the URL of a video. What is the video resource ID? It is the final part of the stream URL. The most important point in this lesson is to distinguish who is going to broadcast the video: you or another provider.

title: How to cast video

you or another provider. Third-party broadcasting: others are going to do the broadcasting In-house broadcasting: you are going to do the broadcasting.

title: Introduction
text:
[Introduction] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
If you have an active and updated Live application you can use it for virtual races. Race management in Copernico in a virtual event is exactly the same as in a regular one. The only difference is the source which you take the data from: In a regular (physical) race Copernico uses tag readings from TSOne, TS2, TSActive, TSPortable or any other device. In a virtual race Copernico receives GPX routes and turns them into raw times.

title: Introduction
text:
[Introduction] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
In a virtual race Copernico receives GPX routes and turns them into raw times. A virtual race in Copernico is set up the same way as in a classic, regular race and all the same operations are carried out, for example, assigning a wave. In this lesson we are going to explain step by step how to create a virtual race and what are small differences between a virtual race and a regular one to take into account when setting it up: Main features of a virtual race

title: Introduction
text:

title: Recomendations _ clarifications
text:

There are certian points that you should keep in mind: Participants are not displayed in this "Live Results" until they have been imported into Cop√©rnico. In a virtual race this does not happen until they complete their participation. In a conventional race, you will do the import manually. Athlete tracking can only be done if the participants have been imported to Cop√©rnico. Only previously setup information will be displayed in the application. If you did not

title: Recomendations _ clarifications
text:
[Recomendations _ clarifications] (Live & Virtual Races > Live Results)
Only previously setup information will be displayed in the application. If you did not setup trophies, these will not be displayed, if team types with their corresponding rankings have not been created, they will not be displayed neither, etc. We recommend that you never intend to set up Live Results on the same race day, unless you're timing a night race.

title: Import of registered participants for their validation
text:
[Import of registered participants for their validation] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
In a regular race participants are managed directly in Copernico. That is, you need to previously import your list to Copernico to time them. In a virtual race you do not need to have participants in Copernico before timing. Any participant of a virtual race should be validated in an intermediate table external of Copernico . There are two ways of introducing data into this intermediate table: Via API: to transfer data from your registration platform to the intermediate table. If 1.

title: Main features of a virtual race
text:
[Main features of a virtual race] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
Virtual races are not difficult to set up, but they do have extra complexity: their data sources come from multiple environments. It means you should know the Sportmaniacs environment as well as the Copernico one to time such types of events. The main differences in the timing of a virtual race in comparison to a regular one are: Start and finish dates of virtual events are setup in a specially designed space. 1. Registred participants of a virtual race are placed in an intermediate table. 2.

title: Main features of a virtual race
text:
[Main features of a virtual race] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
1. Registred participants of a virtual race are placed in an intermediate table. 2. Participants are then validated against this intermediate table. Once they complete their participation, it will be created in Copernico. Participants can always train before events start. 3. There can exist races with both virtual events and physical events: so called hybrid 4. races. But an event cannot be hybrid, it is whether physical or virtual, since an event

text:

4. races. But an event cannot be hybrid, it is whether physical or virtual, since an event cannot receive and process readings from two different sources. An event cannot process gpx files and receive readings from timing equipment. Virtual events can be configured whether for a free route (participants can go 5. anywhere they wish) or a fixed route (participants should complete a pre-established route). Virtual races offer you a possibility to sell races without having to provide the entire 6.

title: Main features of a virtual race

route). Virtual races offer you a possibility to sell races without having to provide the entire 6. infrastructure of a physical event. At the moment, the number of times an athlete can participate in a virtual event 7. cannot be limited. That is, if participation in the event is open for two days, athletes can participate on both day 1 and day 2. You can now keep your registration open in Sportmaniacs together with participation 8.

title: Timing your race
text:
[Timing your race] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
The task of timing a virtual race is exactly the same as that of an on-site race. Just as in the timing of an on-site race, in a virtual race the first thing you have to do is to start it. When you give the start, Cop√©rnico begins to process the data that arrives, generate raws, generate times of the participants and their positions. As you know, in the case of a virtual race there are no timing devices sending the readings,

title: Timing your race
text:
[Timing your race] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
As you know, in the case of a virtual race there are no timing devices sending the readings, but it will be the mobile devices of the runners or the athletes themselves who will upload the GPX tracks with their participations. When Cop√©rnico receives the GPX file from an athlete, the participant is created in the participants section. That is to say, until the participations are uploaded, complete or not, no participants appear in Cop√©rnico.

title: Timing your race
text:
[Timing your race] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
participants appear in Cop√©rnico. Cop√©rnico will transform each GPX into a raw of each participant and will assign times to each of the splits of the event. A unique view in virtual races is the "routes" view of each participant. When you right click on any participant that has an entry you will see the "Routes" option. If you click on it you will see the information of that entry. The information displayed in this dashboard can help you with incident resolution:

title: Timing your race
text:
[Timing your race] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
The information displayed in this dashboard can help you with incident resolution: Participation Id: this is a unique id that is created with each of the participations that are uploaded. It is used internally to distinguish one participation from another. Created: date and time when the participation was created in Cop√©rnico. This data, in entries uploaded with the phone and the Live application, must coincide approximately

title: Timing your race
text:
[Timing your race] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
entries uploaded with the phone and the Live application, must coincide approximately with the race time plus the start time. In participations uploaded from the importer, this data will coincide with the time at which we have uploaded the file, this can be several days later. . Start time: date and time at which the participation started. Accumulated elevation gain: for information purposes. There is a specific column with this data that you can see in "Participants".

title: Timing your race
text:
[Timing your race] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
with this data that you can see in "Participants". Total distance: it is the total distance of the GPX file that has been uploaded with that participation. You can have a file with a shorter distance than the one required by the event, in this case Cop√©rnico will invalidate this participation. Total time: total time of the GPX file. It will be related to the distance covered. These last two values; total distance and total time are very useful to solve incidences.

title: Timing your race
text:
[Timing your race] (Live & Virtual Races > Virtual Races)
These last two values; total distance and total time are very useful to solve incidences. For example, you may find that the participation of an athlete has not reached 10 km, it has remained in 9'9 km. In this case, the total time of the participation can be used

to set the final time. Estos dos √∫ltimos datos; distancia total y tiempo total vienen muy bien para resolver incidencias. Por ejemplo, puedes encontrarte que la participaci√≥n de un atleta no haya llegado a los 10 Km, se haya quedado en 9‚Äô9 km. En ese caso, el tiempo total de la participaci√≥n podr√°s utilizarlo para poner el tiempo final. Adem√°s, en el panel ‚ÄúRuta‚Äù podr√°s: Descargar el archivo GPX de esa participaci√≥n y ver la ruta que ha seguido ese participante.

title: Timing your race

Descargar el archivo GPX de esa participaci√≥n y ver la ruta que ha seguido ese participante. Recalcular raws: si se te ha olvidado crear los splits puedes recalcular las raws de cada participaci√≥n para que se asignen correctamente los tiempos a los splits. Tambi√©n lo puedes usar si el archivo GPX no se ha procesado correctamente.

Usando el Preview. La segunda pesta√±a del plugin de WorkÔ¨Çows nos permite previsualizar el workÔ¨Çow en un dispositivo "virtual" Las opciones que tenemos nos permiten: Selecionar un dispositivo tipo del listado, ajustandose la preview a este dispositivo. Ver la resoluci√≥n del dispositivo y cambiar su zoom. Colocar el dispositivo apaisado. Mediante la imagen del dispositivo simulado podremos operar en el WorkÔ¨Çow, comprobando su funcionamiento para aplicar luego cambios si se requiere.

title: Confirm - Fase de Confirmacion
text:
[Confirm - Fase de Confirmacion] (Copernico Workflows > Creando y configurando un Workflow)
ConÔ¨Årm - Fase de conÔ¨Årmaci√≥n Activar conÔ¨Årmaci√≥n: este paso no es obligatorio a la hora de realizar un WorkÔ¨Çow, por tanto podremos indicar si queremos o no que aparezca marcando la casilla. Color: permite distinguir por colores cada paso dentro del WorkÔ¨Çow. Titulo: nombre que se va a mostrar a este paso/secci√≥n en el WorkÔ¨Çow. Por ejemplo, "ConÔ¨Årmaci√≥n" Info: se puede dejar en blanco. Se puede a√±adir informaci√≥n al t√≠tulo para un mayor entendimiento de la persona que ejecuta el WorkÔ¨Çow.

title: Confirm - Fase de Confirmacion
text:

entendimiento de la persona que ejecuta el WorkÔ¨Çow. Skip time: Indicaremos el tiempo que va a mostrar los datos de conÔ¨Årmaci√≥n. Una vez pasado este tiempo, el WorkÔ¨Çow volver√° al inicio. Resumen de los campos: podr√°s a√±adir los campos necesarios para veriÔ¨Åcar que el proceso se ha realizado al atleta correcto. Una vez creado el WorkÔ¨Çow pulsa en guardar en la esquina superior derecha.

title: Workflows creados
text:
[Workflows creados] (Copernico Workflows > Creando y configurando un Workflow)
Una vez guardado nuestro primer workflow el men√∫ mostrar√°: El boton de "+ADD" para a√±adir nuevos Workflow. Un QR para acceder, identificandonos mediante el uso del PIN, a cualquiera de los Workflows creados. Una lista de los workflows creados. Cada Workflow de la lista tiene una serie de opciones Siendo estas, de izquierda a derecha: Abrir el enlace al Workflow. Copiar el enlace de acceso al Workflow. Visualizar el QR de acceso al Workflow. Abrir la configuraci√≥n. Eliminar el Workflow.
